oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Dora Corrine Adams Johnson, 1920s
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Original black and white photograph of Dora Corrine Adams Johnson seated outside in a chair. The back of the photograph includes biographical information including the name of her husband and his children and grandchildren. Dora Corinne Adams Johnson (1882-1952) was the daughter of Samuel Adams and Elmirah Adams. Samuel Adams was born into slavery in South Carolina and Elmirah is belived to be a Native American. Dora Corinne Adams Johnson was born in 1882, and was a member of St. James CME in Collierville, Tennessee, a church founded by her father. She later attended Mt. Pisgah CME in Orange Mound, Memphis, Tennessee. At both churches she acted as a stewardess, assisting in giving communion during church services. She died in 1952 and is buried at St. James CME Church Cemetery in Collierville, Tennessee.

Portraiture was a highly political activity for African Americans, especially after Emancipation. Frederick Douglass considered photography the most democratic of arts and a crucial aid in African Americans' quest to achieve citizenship because it served as a potent equalizer. Early photographs of African Americans are linked to the first phase of a way of thinking defined as Racial Uplift: an ideology which emphasized education, achievement, and propriety as marks of personal distinction that would refute racist stereotypes and establish a basis for positive Black identities. Photography became the way African Americans visually documented their efforts for full citizenship and political enfranchisement.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Johnson, Dora Corrine Adams, 1882-1952
